name: TRS 80 PC-4
speed: 455 kHz ceramic resonator used as system clock
ram: 1 KB (544 bytes for Basic programs) up to 2 KB
text: 1 line x 12 chars plus a 4 digit seven segment display part
ports: 12-pin expansion port for printer and cassette interface11-pin internal slot for memory module
description:
The Tandy PC-4 Was a rebadged version of the Casio PB-100.
Apart from the brand/model plate, the design and features was identical to the original Casio model.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated 1985 <br><br> "I pianote, it takes note"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QD VERSION ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>1980 Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Our new QD model has all of the features of our phenomenally popular SuperBrain with the addition of double-sided disk drives and an extra of dynamic RAM. So, for only a modest increase in price, you can order your next SuperBrain with more than twice the disk and memory storage capability. But, best of all, the new QD model has the same tough, rugged construction and exceptional quality that made our SuperBrain such a success. </font>  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption.  <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This surprising advert is dated 1982.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"EPSON HX-20: the world most powerful portative micro-computer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The personal computer of Mr sales manager"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, software in profusion"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Adopt a little gifted"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> With NEC's PC-8800 personal computer, you don't have to ask yourself which comes first, the hardware or the software.<br> It's designed to be uncompromising in both areas. So you come first. In the office or at home.<br> The hardware gives you your choice of 8-bit or 16-bit processors, 5 1/4" or 8" disk drives and standard green or high resolution color monitor.<br> The software includes advanced, user friendly programs for all types of banking, accounting and business management. Plus free WordStar word processing, and MailMerge, Multiplan spread sheet, BASIC (two versions), and CP/M... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

With the knowledge that Mitsubishi is the largest manufacturer of Mainframe computers in Japan, those in the know will immediately recognise the true potential of the Mitsubishi F-series...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Carefully, one last time... I compared everything and I offered myself a BBC" <br><br> Lucky guy, he must be rich at more than 6300fr the BBC... At the end of the text we can read : <br><br> "The price : 6300fr maximum. Of course it's not given. More expensive than some (but I had already eliminated them)." !! <br><br> At least they are honest.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>''For less than 2000 francs, offer yourself the future''  ...yes</blockquote>
